item.description: For the latest episode of our podcast series, Senior Editor Rumbi Chakamba sits down with Managing Editor Anna Gawel and Global Development Reporter Elissa Miolene to discuss the top stories from the past week.

item.title: Guatemalan Peasants Overcome Drought in the Dry Corridor
item.description: Water scarcity that relentlessly hits the rural communities in eastern Guatemala, located in the so-called Central American Dry Corridor, is a constant threat due to the challenges in producing food, year after year. item.title: From obstacles to outcomes: Transforming breast cancer care in Rwanda
item.description: Breaking down barriers to care by helping to improve breast cancer survival rates in Rwanda — and advancing quality health care for all.

item.title: How development job seekers can make the most of their time
item.description: During a recent digital event, social impact career coach Kelsi Kriitmaa shared strategies to help job seekers manage their time, energy, and focus more effectively as they navigate a competitive market.

item.title: Devex CheckUp: ‘America First,’ but what about PEPFAR?
item.description: The Trump administration's new global health strategy will undermine PEPFAR’s lifesaving capacity. Plus, how to fund tuberculosis, and heat-related deaths soar.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet in emergency session on Sudan
item.description: As reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war, the Security Council is meeting in emergency session to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. Civilians are facing starvation and mass displacement as the UN continues providing lifesaving aid throughout the country. Hospitals, schools and IDP camps are under attack, with entire neighborhoods emptied as families flee the RSF militia. Follow our in-depth live coverage; UN News app users can go here.

item.title: ‘Blood on the sand. Blood on the hands’: UN decries world’s failure as Sudan’s El Fasher falls
item.description: El Fasher has “descended into an even darker hell,” senior UN officials warned on Thursday, as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia seized control of the North Darfur capital after a 500-day siege, forcing tens of thousands to flee on foot amid reports of mass executions, rape and starvation.

item.title: The cuts that bleed: What happens when peace programs go dark
